column147:
Selenium only provides the core API, but modern users need a complete package with all the setup or a CLI that handles everything.

Building a framework from scratch is challenging and difficult to maintain. It lacks plug-and-play functionality, requiring everything to be configurable.

column145:
In terms of architecture and governance Selenium is best.
We still prefer it for large TypeScript code base becase for us the most important is to minimize the risk (for me using tools like Cypress and Plawright is higher risk).
For smaller and not long term TypeScript projects I would try Plawright becase of better development exerience and TypeScript support.

column24: Using Docker with Selenium
column103: To solve all these challenges I’m focused on optimising the execution time by using both parallel execution and headless browser. Also, I use explicit waits to handle async int., and the most important I follow the POM to keep my scripts maintainable. For debugging I use logging to track all issues. I also use Docker to create isolated test env.
column104:
I believe I’d ask first for a better native mobile support, that would be really helpful as we currently rely on Appium. Also it would be nice to have a built in visual regression for screenshots, to compare them. 
And a top if in the nearest future Selenium would offer a built in assertion methods for common tasks, this would reduce the need for all third-party libraries and make tests more efficient
column138: Integration issues, inconsistent maintenance… bias in suggestions
column145:
I don’t like to directly compare Playwright and Selenium because they both serve different purposes. Playwright is a framework while Selenium is a great tool. 
Playwright has some advantages in terms of being faster, supports multiple browser, it’s easier to setup for parallel test execution, it has built in auto waiting and browser context management that really reduce the flaky tests…
column146: I believe because it’s newer and has few resources and again if to check the community support with Selenium(which has been longer around), the ecosystem it’s smaller, and less jobs opportunities:)
column147: If the team or stakeholders decide to move to Playwright I’d just adapt to that, even if I really like Selenium, and I still believe it will continue to improve with future versions. But still if Playwright becomes the choice, whether it is for benefits or a new job role requiring it, I’d make the transition. Selenium still has its place, and I’m confident it will evolve to stay competitive.

column103: **None** of the previous problems are Selenium specific. All are problems common across with test automation and its tooling. Flakiness and Async and part of slowness I resolve with custom implicit waiting based upon the frontend tech stack. Maintainability, failure analysis, and scalability I resolve with good test architecture along with a little of brittleness. Brittleness also get resolved by working with the larger devel and product teams.
column104: Missing not only from Selenium but within the WebDriver spec is tight integration with accessibility testing/tooling. (Thus agreement with assetability although I say that for only a18y issuesnoth ings like network or performance which iw oud use other tools) I am just starting to explore this area but in disucssing with others this seems like a missing gap within the Selenium / WebDriver tech stack

Using a language-specific manager (e.g., WebDriverManager in Java, webdriver-manager in Python, etc.)
column103:
1) slowness: I always use implicit waits or explicit waits, reducing the number of thread sleeps as much as possible 
2) brittleness: I use robust locators (i.e. IDs) when possible 
3) flakiness: I always use waiting strategies. When developing a test, I run it multiple times to see if it's flaky 
4) maintainability: I use robust locators 
5) asynchronous: I use waiting strategies 
6) failure analysis: I mainly rely on the stacktrace of the exception to see what interaction is causing the failure. In the most complex cases, I run the test in a full window to see what is actually happening before and during the failure 
7) scalability: I reduce the number of parallel test execution on the same machine 
8) assertability: I never had the necessity to assert on visual properties
column104: Robust locator generation via direct inspection of the web page

column24: Using a language-specific manager (e.g., WebDriverManager in Java, webdriver-manager in Python, etc.)
column103: For the fragility problem I tend to use ID-based (when IDs are non autogenerated) or relative XPath locators, known to be more robust. For the flakiness, I rely on explicit waits or sleep to synch the executions, although they can still fail. For scalability and maintainability I tend to use locators that are more readable in terms of values, by also assigning them to variables with meaningful names, logically organizing tests in classes and using the Page Object pattern for code reuse.
